title: [Styled-Components] Increase PERF 10x

labels.name: Popular package
labels.description: This PR affects a popular package (as counted by NPM download counts).

labels.name: Perf: Better
labels.description: typescript-bot determined that this PR improves compilation performance.

labels.name: Untested Change
labels.description: This PR does not touch tests

body:
Working on an improvement experience of typing with "stitches" I noticed that typing `keyof JSX.IntrinsicElements` is insanely costly. By rather using `string` through the typing and rather `extend` at the very end, we gain an insane performance boost.

The only downside to this is that the "as" prop is now typed as a string. But, I would argue that we do not need to type it as anything else, since it is just name of HTML elements. It will still throw an error if invalid as we `extend` it at the end. And the performance boost is such a huge improvement.

title: [eslint][RFC] Update SourceCode with TokenReturnType for accurate typing of filter predicates

labels.name: Self Merge
labels.description: This PR can now be self-merged by the PR author or an owner

labels.name: Perf: Same
labels.description: typescript-bot determined that this PR will not significantly impact compilation performance.

body:
This PR updates the types for SourceCode so that the return type takes `includeComments` and any filter predicates into account.

The types as they're currently defined aren't wrong, but they are overly broad. `includeComments` defaults to false (e.g. [here](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/6791decfc58b7b09cfd0aabd15a3d14148aae073/lib/source-code/token-store/index.js#L78)). Filter predicates do just that. However, if you currently use a type guard in filter, it will have no effect on the resulting type (see modifications to existing test cases).

This PR achieves return type refinement by making these methods generic on their options, and then using a type transformer to compute the actual return type conditioned on the options. If a filter with a predicate is used, then it uses the predicate return type, otherwise it only returns comments if `includeComments` is true.

I called this an RFC for two main reasons.
1. I think this is an improvement because it makes the types more accurate, but it also makes the types more complicated which could
   a. hurt type checking performance
   b. make the type signatures less readable
   I'm open to the argument that slightly more refined types is not worth those two negatives and therefore this shouldn't be checked in.
2. I think this is probably the most elegant way to achieve this, but there might be others and am open to different ways to narrow the return types.

If changing an existing definition:
- [x] Provide a URL to documentation or source code which provides context for the suggested changes: <<https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/6791decfc58b7b09cfd0aabd15a3d14148aae073/lib/source-code/token-store/index.js#L78>>

title: Partial clone instructions
body:
A suggestion to include partial cloning instructions in the README. No packages modified.

With the partial clone method listed, (1) blobs are retrieved only when required and (2) type packages have to be explicitly checked out. As a result, the file size for initial cloning was reduced from >1GB to 328MB. Git performance is also improved, which was noticeably lagging on a Core i7 with 32GB of memory (and many instances of Chrome running).

Further reading on the methods used:
- https://github.blog/2020-12-21-get-up-to-speed-with-partial-clone-and-shallow-clone/
- https://github.blog/2020-01-17-bring-your-monorepo-down-to-size-with-sparse-checkout/

title: StyledComponent: More accurate component constraint for TS 4.2

labels.name: Popular package
labels.description: This PR affects a popular package (as counted by NPM download counts).

labels.name: Owner Approved
labels.description: A listed owner of this package signed off on the pull request.

labels.name: Perf: Same
labels.description: typescript-bot determined that this PR will not significantly impact compilation performance.

labels.name: Untested Change
labels.description: This PR does not touch tests

body:
This change makes styled-components pass compilation on Typescript 4.2, which correctly propagates type parameter constraints through certain
complex conditional types. Old versions of typescript just dropped the constraint by mistake, so this inconsistency was just not checked before.

I'm not certain this is the right solution; in particular, it may be a lot slower. I hope not, because I have no idea what the right fix is otherwise!

Edit: 

1. performance looks OK.
2. I haven't tried it, but changing all `keyof JSX.Intrinsic` to `string` might also fix the error, at the cost of some type accuracy.

title: fix(@types/styled-system__css): build performance issues with `css` function

labels.name: Popular package
labels.description: This PR affects a popular package (as counted by NPM download counts).

labels.name: Perf: Same
labels.description: typescript-bot determined that this PR will not significantly impact compilation performance.

body:
When we intensively use the function `css`, typescript declaration files are really slow to compile and generated files are huge.

This is due to `css` return type being inlined for every usage of the function.

To fix the issue, we just export the return type, so it can be reused

Here is a reproduction https://github.com/ardeois/style-components-slow-compilation

|                   | Before |  After  |
| :---------: | :-----: | :-----: |
| Build time |  19s     | 3s |
| File size    |   1.2MB      | 9.1KB  |


> Note on an internal project using  `styled-system/css` our build takes 4 minutes, and is down to 30 seconds with this fix.

title: [har-format] PostData has mutually exclusive text and params props

labels.name: Popular package
labels.description: This PR affects a popular package (as counted by NPM download counts).

labels.name: Self Merge
labels.description: This PR can now be self-merged by the PR author or an owner

labels.name: Owner Approved
labels.description: A listed owner of this package signed off on the pull request.

labels.name: Perf: Same
labels.description: typescript-bot determined that this PR will not significantly impact compilation performance.

body:
## Summary

Right now there is a bug in the HAR typings: a `PostData` object requires both `text` and `params` props to be set, even though the standard explicitly says:
> Note that text and params fields are mutually exclusive.

This PR implements a mutually exclusive `text` and `params` field on a `PostData` object. 
Tests are added.

title: [node] Update some apis

labels.name: Perf: Same
labels.description: typescript-bot determined that this PR will not significantly impact compilation performance.

body:
- [x] Add `assert.CallTracker` - [was added in 14.2.0](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/doc/changelogs/CHANGELOG_V14.md#track-function-calls-with-assertcalltracker-experimental)
- [x] Add `crypto.getFips` to latest version - I missed it in #47298
- [x] Add `AsyncResource.bind` - [was added in 14.8.0](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/doc/changelogs/CHANGELOG_V14.md#2020-08-11-version-1480-current-codebytere)
- [x] Deprecate `module.parent` - [14.6.0](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/doc/changelogs/CHANGELOG_V14.md#2020-07-21-version-1460-current-mylesborins)
- [x] Add `PerformanceNodeTiming.idleTime` - [were added in 14.10.0](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/doc/changelogs/CHANGELOG_V14.md#2020-09-08-version-14100-current-richardlau)
- [x] Remove old properties from `PerformanceNodeTiming` and `Performance` - [were removed from 10.0.0 docs](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/21247) and [from code](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/19563) [later](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/29528)
- [x] Add `process.mainModule` and `process.umask()` - they [were deprecated in 14.0.0](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/doc/changelogs/CHANGELOG_V14.md#2020-04-21-version-1400-current-bethgriggs) but still available.

title: chore: Use actions/checkout@v2 for pull requests
Fix react-router hooks test

labels.name: Self Merge
labels.description: This PR can now be self-merged by the PR author or an owner

labels.name: Perf: Same
labels.description: typescript-bot determined that this PR will not significantly impact compilation performance.

body:
microsoft/TypeScript#39081, which ships in Typescript 4.0, stops using binding patterns as contextual types for return type inference. react-router's `useParams` relied on this to fill in an object with `any`s in case a binding pattern was used but no type argument was provided. This no longer works in 4.0.

This fix just adds a type argument to the tests to reflect what users of TS 4.0 will have to do to use react-router.

For two other, more complete fixes, see

https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/39081#issuecomment-644393729

Briefly, the options are (1) go back to returning `any`-filled object types or (2) tries to default to `string`.

The second fix is probably the right one, but it may hurt compilation/IDE performance, so I'll leave it to the contributors to decide whether to make that change.

title: [lodash] Placeholder support

labels.name: Other Approved
labels.description: This PR was reviewed and signed-off by a community member.

labels.name: Popular package
labels.description: This PR affects a popular package (as counted by NPM download counts).

labels.name: Author is Owner
labels.description: The author of this PR is a listed owner of the package.

body:
- Placeholder support for curried functions
- Placeholder support for auto-curried `fp` functions (fixes #24602)
- Support importing `"lodash/fp/placehoder"` and the alias `"lodash/fp/__"`

Unfortunately, since this required adding a ridiculous number of new overloads, it caused the tests to run out of memory. To fix the tests, I needed to do the following:
- Removed parameterless generated overloads (e.g. `interface LodashPick { (): LodashPick; ... }`). I don't see any use case for these overloads (they don't really do anything), so I removed them to free up some space.
- Removed all jsdoc comments from the `fp` function definitions. This is unfortunate, but it made the biggest difference by far in the performance of the tests.
- Combined FP code into one file. Now all function definitions are inside `fp.d.ts`, instead of being distributed among hundreds of files. Unfortunately this change makes the diff very hard to read, but it's necessary in order to make the tests pass.

So there are some drawbacks, but I think the value of placeholder support outweighs them all.

title: Make reactstrap compile faster

labels.name: Popular package
labels.description: This PR affects a popular package (as counted by NPM download counts).

body:
This reverts the strictness part of #26094 without changing its
interface. It retains

1. string index signatures, so that arbitrary props can be passed in.
2. extending from React.Componenent, so that individual types can be subclassed.
3. Type parameters on the individual types.

However, string index signatures can no longer be avoided, and type parameters are ignored. This preserves interface compatibility -- existing code will not break from this change -- but disables excess prop checking. It's possible that a breaking change that returns the type package to its old strict behaviour can be made at the same time as a breaking change of reactstrap itself.

This change improves performance dramatically, and allows linting to succeed without running out of memory. This will unblock changes to `@types/react`, since reactstrap is tested as part of react's CI tests.

```
== Before (3.3.4000) ==
Files:              98
Lines:           63288
Nodes:          201816
Identifiers:     63784
Symbols:        961453
Types:          493230
Memory used:   601673K
I/O Read time:   0.02s
Parse time:      0.39s
Program time:    0.45s
Bind time:       0.22s
Check time:     10.03s
Total time:     10.70s

=== After 2 (3.3.4000) ===
Files:              98
Lines:           63255
Nodes:          200300
Identifiers:     63132
Symbols:        178691
Types:           80350
Memory used:   179229K
I/O Read time:   0.01s
Parse time:      0.41s
Program time:    0.47s
Bind time:       0.23s
Check time:      4.60s
Total time:      5.29s
```

After the first commit, the number of types is just over 337,000. On `typescript@next`, Before had 1.5 million types, and After had 107,000 types.

title: Make lodash faster

labels.name: Revision needed
labels.description: This PR needs code changes before it can be merged.

labels.name: New Definition
labels.description: This PR creates a new definition package.

labels.name: Popular package
labels.description: This PR affects a popular package (as counted by NPM download counts).

labels.name: Owner Approved
labels.description: A listed owner of this package signed off on the pull request.

body:
This change makes lodash faster for Typescript versions 3.1 and above. 

The principle change is to undo most of #19356, which implemented the chaining methods of lodash via two interfaces. Each interface contains all the methods of lodash, and each methods has overloads for each of the types supported by lodash -- list or object, for example. The overloads are distinguished by their `this` parameter. Something like this:

```ts
interface Wrapper<T> {
  map<U, V>(this: List<U>, f: (u: U) => V): Wrapper<List<V>>;
  map<U, V>(this: Dictionary<U>, f: (u: U) => V): Wrapper<List<V>>;
}
```

This is abysmally slow. With Typescript 3.3, completions take 8 seconds or so to show up. After this PR, they take 1 second. With Typescript 3.4, both the compiler and language service often run out of memory, but this is due to 3.4's over-reliance on structural comparison. 3.5 will return performance to that of 3.3.

It creates a gigantic type with every method in lodash, and each method has many overloads, and each overload is generic. And each overload has an extra parameter, the `this` parameter, that is almost always generic, and almost always a union. In order to compare instances of lodash wrappers, each method must be instantiated, including every one of its overloads. That means each overload must be instantiated, including every one of its parameters.

Using `this` parameters to dual-dispatch at compile-time is clever, but has two usability drawbacks as well:

1. Error messages are "The this-context 'number' does not match the type of the this parameter 'List<T> | null | undefined' for 'map'.", not "'map' is not found on 'Primitive'".
2. The language service attempts to work around this by filtering methods by their this context. However, this is extremely slow.

This PR changes lodash to use an inheritance hierarchy instead. `LodashImplicitWrapper` now has five subtypes: `Collection`, `Object`, `Function`, `String` and `Primitive`. Lodash's call signature now has overloads that produce each of these wrapper types.

With an inheritance hierarchy, LodashImplicitWrapper contains the shared methods that truly apply the same way to all types. Then each subtype contains type-specific methods. Each method has many fewer overloads -- often none at all -- and is usually not generic. And the number of parameters shrinks greatly without this parameters everywhere. It also means that error messages and language service responsiveness improve.

The two drawbacks are:

1. More duplicated code, in particular methods like `concat` that apply *almost* the same way to each type, except for `Collection`. `Collection` can't unsoundly override a `concat` from `LodashImplicitWrapper`, so each subtype has to have its own `concat`.
2. For `any`, showing all methods that *might* apply can be helpful for JS users. However, I think the situation is not that bad right now, and can perhaps be improved. `any` has its own overload with `_(any)`, which currently returns `Collection<any>` but could return an intersection type.

Notes on implementation:

1. The non-chaining methods are barely changed. There are some inefficiencies there, but the scale is pretty small since `LodashStatic` is never instantiated; it's just a big collection of generic signatures.
2. The implementation uses conditional types and modern mapped-type distributivity to retain most of the chaining from the previous implementation. That is, if a List.reduce returns an object, it will be wrapped in an Object wrapper. If it returns a number, it will be wrapped in a Primitive wrapper. However, the conditional type is only used where it produces a better type — about 25 times. Most functions in lodash don't change the container type.
Using modern features makes this PR possible, but means that older versions of Typescript can't take advantage of it. I put the new code in a `ts3.1/` subdirectory so that both versions can be maintained until 2.x is old enough to drop support for.
3. The most interesting part of the code is `common/common.d.ts` and `common/seq.d.ts`, which have the implicit chain constructor and explicit chain constructor, respectively.
5. lowdb relies on lodash's chaining API, but created a copy of it using a script. The only thing the copy is used for is to distinguish the return type of `write` between the sync and async API in lowdb. Since lowdb is a rarely used package, and the return type of `write` is rarely used, I instead fudged its return type as `T & Promise<T>`, combined the sync and async APIs, and got rid of the script-generated copy.

title: [react] Add some support for special cases using undefined with hooks

labels.name: Popular package
labels.description: This PR affects a popular package (as counted by NPM download counts).

labels.name: Author is Owner
labels.description: The author of this PR is a listed owner of the package.

labels.name: Owner Approved
labels.description: A listed owner of this package signed off on the pull request.

body:
After some further discussion about this in https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/issues/30780 and on twitter, I thought about "solving the problem" once and for all with an official warning, but @sebmarkbage's position on this is more [in favor of just being explicit](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/14894#issuecomment-465433212) than it being specifically necessary for correctness and/or performance reasons.

Given how in TypeScript it is possible to, through the use of overloads with specific arities and generic defaults, support this use case safely, I added some overloads with very specific constraints that allow you to omit the arguments to `useRef` and `useState`. `useReducer` could follow the same logic but its' typing situation is a lot more complicated and it's in need of a different refactoring; so for now it stays being 2-ary.

As for `useMemo`, I didn't allow the inputs list to be undefined for somewhat opinionated reasons (it's normally not very useful to memoize without a key); but there's at least one use case that's possibly not user error (see [this tweet](https://twitter.com/jessidhia/status/1093155905997234176)), so allow the caller to explicitly pass `undefined` to hopefully indicate you know what you are doing.

This was not done with `useCallback` because there's no use case for it. The equivalent of `useCallback(foo, undefined)` is `useMemo(() => foo, undefined)`, which is `foo` itself.

- [x] Use a meaningful title for the pull request. Include the name of the package modified.
- [x] Test the change in your own code. (Compile and run.)
- [x] Follow the advice from the [readme](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/README.md#make-a-pull-request).
- [x] Avoid [common mistakes](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/README.md#common-mistakes).
- [x] Run `npm run lint package-name` (or `tsc` if no `tslint.json` is present).
- [x] Provide a URL to documentation or source code which provides context for the suggested changes: https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/pull/1832 and https://github.com/storybooks/storybook/blob/master/MIGRATION.md#refactored-knobs
- [x] Increase the version number in the header if appropriate.
- [ ] If you are making substantial changes, consider adding a `tslint.json` containing `{ "extends": "dtslint/dt.json" }`.

The Storybook knobs add-on has changed its API due to the support of more frameworks. The old way of importing from `@storybook/addon-knobs` is still available but deprecated. The right way (without performance penalty of importing all frameworks) is to import the specific version, e.g.:

* In the case of React: `import { withKnobs, text, boolean, number } from '@storybook/addon-knobs/react';`
* In the case of Vue: `import { ... } from '@storybook/addon-knobs/vue';`
* In the case of Angular: `import { ... } from '@storybook/addon-knobs/angular';`

Locally, for TS this is currently broken due to the changes in knobs, I added a d.ts file locally:
```
declare module '@storybook/addon-knobs/react' {
  export * from '@storybook/addon-knobs';
}
```
which works there, but I am unsure about this approach within DefinitelyTyped, @martynaskadisa @andy-ms any ideas?

title: Increase nProcesses from 4 to 8
body:
| Run | --nProcesses 4 | --nProcesses 8 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | 15 min 12 sec | 9 min 53 sec |
| 2 | 14 min 27 sec | 9 min 59 sec |
| 3 | 13 min 29 sec | 11 min 19 sec |
| **Avg** | 14 min 23 sec | 10 min 24 sec |

@andy-ms I'm not sure if https://github.com/Microsoft/types-publisher/pull/358 is going to be able to be pulled in or not. It'd be nice to get the performance benefit from going to 4 processes per core though (especially if we end up [doing more tests](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/issues/17626)).

title: [tough-cookie][electron-settings][semantic-ui-*] Fix weak type workaround
body:
Please fill in this template.

- [x] Use a meaningful title for the pull request. Include the name of the package modified.
- [x] Test the change in your own code. (Compile and run.)
- [x] Follow the advice from the [readme](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/README.md#make-a-pull-request).
- [x] Avoid [common mistakes](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/README.md#common-mistakes).
- [x] Run `npm run lint package-name` (or `tsc` if no `tslint.json` is present).

Select one of these and delete the others:

If changing an existing definition:
- ~~Provide a URL to documentation or source code which provides context for the suggested changes:~~
- ~~Increase the version number in the header if appropriate.~~
- ~~If you are making substantial changes, consider adding a `tslint.json` containing `{ "extends": "dtslint/dt.json" }`.~~

I've reverted the weak type workaround for `@types/electron-settings` and `@types/tough-cookie`. The Semantic UI packages however are a bit more vulnerable to pre-2.4 weak type behavior.

I'm considering declaring settings types as a union of the types that result from making 1 property required (and the rest optional) and repeating for each property. The resulting union won't be a weak type since each member has 1 required property.

**Example**
```typescript
type StrictOptions = {
    a: boolean;
    b?: string;
} | {
    a?: boolean;
    b: string;
};
```

**Using mapped types**

From [global.d.ts](https://github.com/leonard-thieu/DefinitelyTyped/blob/4afdb3881dacc6e7dd123820a143167247d8a4f9/types/semantic-ui-accordion/global.d.ts#L42):
```typescript
type Param = (Pick<_Impl, 'exclusive'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'on'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'animateChildren'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'closeNested'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'collapsible'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'duration'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'easing'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'observeChanges'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'onOpening'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'onOpen'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'onClosing'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'onClose'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'onChange'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'selector'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'className'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'error'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'namespace'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'name'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'silent'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'debug'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'performance'> |
    Pick<_Impl, 'verbose'>) &
    Partial<Pick<_Impl, keyof _Impl>>;
```

where `_Impl` is the settings type with all properties non-optional.

---

This _seems_ to work correctly and I believe should work for 2.1+. Would like some feedback on this technique.

title: Enzyme: Restore strongly typed props for classes, misc. updates
body:
This is mainly to fix
`wrapper.find(MyClassComponent).props().someCallbackk(); //oops, typo`
not being caught with the latest TypeScript + definitions. I am not sure where things went wrong for that, but there is a note at the top of index.d.ts around it. The first part of the fix was #14202, but it wasn't quite enough.

Additional changes:

* Add Pick typings for setState/setProps, mirrors #13155
* Fix Cheerio wrapper to reference Cheerio typings (this was incorrect from day 1 I think -- the interfaces are not the same). This let me delete tons of overloads from CommonWrapper, which should help with typecheck performance (Enzyme types have historically caused problems there)
* Remove deprecated APIs (they've been gone for about a year)
* Add tslint and fix errors
* Normalize React+Shallow wrapper tests and add some missing overload tests
* If we're filtered down to a wrapper containing stateless components, the type of wrapper.state() is never

title: Node.js Buffer should be useable as a Uint8Array and is missing a constructor
body:
This is an improvement to an existing type definition.

I work on a browserified project that uses some Node.js libraries - so converting between `ArrayBuffer` and `Buffer` crops up again and again. I was looking into the performance of this - specifically, eliminating byte copying - when I realised two things are missing from the current definition:
1. `Buffer` is also a `Uint8Array`: https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v4.x/docs/api/buffer.html#buffer_buffers_and_typedarray
2. `Buffer` has a constructor which accepts an `ArrayBuffer` and which causes the resulting `Buffer` to share the same memory as the `ArrayBuffer`: https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v4.x/docs/api/buffer.html#buffer_new_buffer_arraybuffer

My solution is to make `NodeBuffer` extend `Uint8Array` and add that missing constructor to `Buffer` - also, remove a couple of methods from `Buffer` which are already defined in `Uint8Array` and a few which are missing.

title: Added type definition for Famous Engine v0.7.1
body: I am adding a type definition for Famous Engine - high-performance javascript library for animations & interfaces

title: Add definition for D3 chargeDistance
body:
The definition for `chargeDistance` function of D3 ForceLayout is missing: [force.chargeDistance([distance])](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/wiki/Force-Layout#chargeDistance).

> #### # force.**chargeDistance**([_distance_])
> 
> If distance is specified, sets the maximum distance over which charge forces are applied. If distance is not specified, returns the current maximum charge distance, which defaults to infinity. Specifying a finite charge distance improves the performance of the force layout and produces a more localized layout; distance-limited charge forces are especially useful in conjunction with custom gravity. For an example, see “Constellations of Directors and their Stars” (The New York Times).

title: Update lodash.d.ts to support TypeScript 1.0
body:
With the removal of parts of the Type Inference system the interface Collection<T> fails to work with List<T>, 0 Array<T>, and Dictionary<T>.  

This change breaks out all instances of Collection<T> into Array<T>, List<T> and Dictionary<T>.  Also we further break out instances of List<T> into Array<T> and List<T> to support Array's and Array Like Objects.  This should address most of the issues found in #1759.

I know this change is a lot more definition code that we previously had, but I do not see TypeScript gaining back the lostType Inference any time soon.  Mainly it seems like the performance loss was too drastic in the compiler.

There are still a few things in the tests that fail, but they have to do with reduce / reduceRight, I did not address those as part of this Pull Request.  It appears for the accumulator to work correctly it has to be strongly typed, and can not be inferred.
